answers.explanation:
There is an elevated choroidal lesion causing undulations in the overlying RPE, along with thickening (red arrow) and irregularity of the RPE. Subretinal fluid (star) and hyperreflective foci in the EZ and RPE (blue arrows) can also be appreciated.

![](/content/media/onc7_3.webp)

Given the patient’s past medical history, the diagnosis is likely a choroidal metastasis. Choroidal metastases typically present as multiple, yellow-white choroidal lesions and may be associated with overlying subretinal fluid.

Choroidal melanomas typically present as dome-shaped, brown-yellow pigmented choroidal lesions, associated with subretinal fluid and orange pigment.

Choroidal nevi are well-circumscribed, typically flat variably pigmented choroidal lesions. They remain stable in size and over time, may be associated with overlying drusen as well as RPE atrophy, hyperplasia or fibrous metaplasia.

The mnemonic “To Find Small Ocular Melanoma Using Helpful Hints Daily” (TFSOM-UHHD) has been proposed to differentiate a choroidal melanoma from a nevus. The mnemonic suggests that a melanoma has a thickness >2 mm, subretinal fluid, symptoms (decreased vision, flashes or floaters), orange pigment, margin within 3 mm of the optic disc, ultrasonographic hollowness, absence of halo (band of depigmentation around pigmented lesion) and absence of drusen.

Choroidal hemangiomas can be diffuse or well-circumscribed, orange-red elevated choroidal lesions, associated with subretinal fluid, orange plaques and RPE atrophy. A key diagnostic feature of choroidal hemangiomas is the patency of sub-RPE vasculature as there is no compression of the choriocapillaris. This contrasts with choroidal melanomas and nevi, which involve compression of the choriocapillaris.

On OCT imaging, a “lumpy bumpy” anterior tumor surface is characteristic of choroidal metastasis (Figure A2), with preservation of the inner retinal layers. Choroidal melanomas (Figure E), nevi (Figure D) and hemangiomas (Figure C) typically appear as gently sloping choroidal masses.

![](/content/media/onc7_4.webp)

![](/content/media/onc7_5.webp)

![](/content/media/onc7_6.webp)

![](/content/media/onc7_7.webp)

Images from Mathis et al. 2019

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: What are other primary sites of choroidal metastasis than breast cancer?

answers.explanation:
The most frequent primary tumor site of choroidal metastasis is breast, which is found in 40–53% of cases. The second most frequent is lung, which is found in 20–29% of cases. Less frequent primary tumors include carcinomas of the GI tract (4%), prostate (2%), kidney (2%), and skin (2%).

References:

Mathis T, Jardel P, Loria O, et al. New concepts in the diagnosis and management of choroidal metastases. Prog Retin Eye Res. 2019;68:144-176. doi:10.1016/j.preteyeres.2018.09.003

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text: In addition to ongoing chemotherapy and/or hormonal therapy, what local therapies can be used to treat this patient?

answers.explanation:
All of these modalities can be used to provide local tumour control and improve visual function. Chemotherapy and/or hormonal therapy are first line in the management of choroidal metastases. The choice of local therapy, especially radiotherapy, depends on the patient’s life expectancy, tumor location, size and number of metastatic foci. Conventional EBRT is the most common treatment for choroidal metastasis and is cost effective. Photodynamic therapy (PDT) and anti-VEGF injections have also been reported as possible office-based treatments of choroidal metastasis.

References:

Mathis T, Jardel P, Loria O, et al. New concepts in the diagnosis and management of choroidal metastases. Prog Retin Eye Res. 2019;68:144-176. doi:10.1016/j.preteyeres.2018.09.003

Chen CJ, McCoy AN, Brahmer J, Handa JT. Emerging treatments for choroidal metastases. Surv Ophthalmol. 2011;56(6):511-521. doi:10.1016/j.survophthal.2011.05.001

questions.title: Question 5
questions.text:
The patient was referred to radiation oncology service and she was treated with EBRT. At three months follow-up, OCT imaging of the left eye revealed a regressed choroidal mass, resolution of all subretinal fluid, with some residual irregularity and disruption within the EZ and the RPE.

![](/content/media/onc7_8.webp)

Fundus photo 3 months post radiation shows resolution of optic nerve swelling and regression of the choroidal mass. The patient’s BCVA was 20/60 at 3 months.

![](/content/media/onc7_9.webp)

What are some complications associated with radiotherapy to the eye?

answers.explanation:
Complications from radiotherapy include radiation retinopathy, radiation papillopathy, and cataracts. These complications develop months or years after irradiation, and therefore are only relevant in patients with a good prognosis.

References:

Stannard C, Sauerwein W, Maree G, Lecuona K. Radiotherapy for ocular tumours. Eye (Lond). 2013;27(2):119-127. doi:10.1038/eye.2012.241

title: Case 7
description: 44F presenting with vision loss OS for 3 weeks
patientPresentation:
**Contributors:** Mohammed Al Falah and Miguel Cruz Pimentel

A 44-year-old female was referred to a tertiary retina centre for vision loss in the left eye for 3 weeks. Her past ocular history was unremarkable. Her past medical history was significant for advanced breast cancer with known bone metastasis requiring chemotherapy. She denied pain or red eye, but she did note occasional flashes in the periphery over the last few days.

On examination, her best corrected visual acuity was 20/25 OD and 20/400 OS. Her IOP was 12 mmHg OD and 15 mmHg OS. The anterior segment examination was normal, with no signs of inflammation. Fundus examination of the right eye was within normal limits. Fundus examination of the left eye revealed a hyperemic optic nerve swelling as well as an elevated non-pigmented choroidal lesion inferior to the optic nerve. The lesion is at least 10 DD in size with an extension to the macula and subfoveal area.
